12.14.text: It's so great to be here and I'm gonna start my talk

14.68.text: with a little logo we all know well.

17.62.text: My story begins when I was in your shoes.

21.12.text: I was a Stanford student and for me,

26.21.text: one of the biggest things that had ever happened to me.

29.03.text: I grew up in a really small town in Rhode Island.

31.52.text: I went to a pretty average public school

33.99.text: and when I found out I got into Stanford,

36.70.text: they announced it on the loudspeaker

38.61.text: and everyone in the cafeteria got up and cheered.

41.54.text: It was that big of a deal

43.20.text: and so as I was preparing to go off to college,

47.50.text: I remember one day my math teacher pulled me aside

50.06.text: and asked me what I planned on majoring in

51.96.text: and at the time, I was a high school senior.

60.36.text: She said that, I've told this story a million times,

62.26.text: but it's so funny because in my head

64.24.text: I pictured an old man driving a train.

68.04.text: I had no idea what engineering was,

70.59.text: but whatever picture I had in my head

72.60.text: was the least appealing interesting thing to me at all

77.04.text: and I kind of thought she was crazy,

79.58.text: but sure enough, I got to Stanford

83.42.text: and my freshman year, I had no idea what I wanted to study

86.88.text: and so I thought why not try engineering?

89.30.text: So I signed up for EMI 101.

92.19.text: I walked into the room and almost just turned right out

95.52.text: and walked out the other way because I looked around

99.01.text: and I saw barely any girls and I thought

102.23.text: I'm not sure if this is really for me,

104.31.text: but luckily I stayed in the class

106.42.text: and I'm really glad that I did

108.00.text: because it was the first time

108.98.text: that I learned what engineering was

110.97.text: and we weren't fixing train engines in that class.

113.65.text: It was an amazing class because it was really

115.55.text: an introduction to just the way the world works.

120.68.text: we learned how to build stuff, how to invent,

124.14.text: It was incredibly creative and inspiring to me

126.14.text: to think that I could be an inventor

127.95.text: and solve big problems in the world.

130.09.text: That was something I was really passionate about

131.74.text: and so I decided I'm gonna study engineering.

134.96.text: From that moment on was the first time

136.49.text: in my life I ever got a C.

138.83.text: It was the first time in my life

140.36.text: I ever struggled and hoped that I would just pass class.

144.00.text: It was the first time in my life

145.32.text: that I really actually challenged myself

150.47.text: I was the only girl in group projects with all guys

153.76.text: and that often felt like they'd look at me

155.72.text: and think, ah, we got stuck with a girl

159.33.text: and I started to feel that way about myself too.

161.26.text: I often felt I wasn't good enough or wasn't smart enough.

164.20.text: I almost dropped out of the major a million times.

166.78.text: I wasn't set up for success from my public school,

170.46.text: not even knowing what engineering was

172.08.text: and looking around and seeing guys in my classes

174.42.text: who had already learned how to program calculators

176.98.text: and already knew how to build a million things,

179.79.text: but luckily I stuck with it.

182.66.text: I studied hard, put in the midnight oil

187.52.text: and I ended up graduating and that day

191.88.text: that I graduated in 2005 was actually the year

194.69.text: that Steve Jobs gave the commencement speech,

197.30.text: so I was there and it was the proudest day of my life

201.84.text: because I had done something hard, you know?

204.77.text: I had really tried something hard

206.48.text: and I'd ended up achieving it

208.35.text: and so that feeling that you get

209.77.text: when you actually really apply yourself

212.21.text: and you climb that mountain and you get to the top,

215.03.text: you feel invincible and that was how I felt

217.43.text: and that was kind of the gift that engineering gave to me,

225.11.text: So years later, I had been searching

229.37.text: ever since that day I graduated to find my passion.

232.09.text: You know, that thing that Steve Jobs said,

236.23.text: I wanted to find that for myself,

237.85.text: but I didn't know what it was

238.93.text: and so I spent about seven years at different jobs

241.50.text: and finally I found it and it happened one day.

244.79.text: I had got together with a group of friends

246.98.text: and we had started this tradition called Idea Brunch

250.21.text: where we'd get together and each person

252.42.text: would get up in front of the group

254.11.text: and share their latest hair-brained idea

256.74.text: for an app or a company or whatever.

258.84.text: Just one of those things you kind of

260.15.text: muse about when you're driving in the car.

262.71.text: Of course, over breakfast and in that session one day,

266.63.text: my friend Christi, who studied engineering

269.02.text: with me here at Stanford got up.

271.07.text: She started complaining about how few women

272.89.text: there were in our engineering classes

275.27.text: and she said, "You know, as a little girl,

283.11.text: "like Legos and Erector Sets and Lincoln Logs

285.90.text: "and that's what got me interested in engineering."

288.83.text: I kind of in that moment thought back to my childhood

291.76.text: growing up with me and my little sister.

293.80.text: We never played with any toys like that at all

297.95.text: and I remember in my engineering classes,

300.36.text: a lot of the assignments that we did

301.89.text: we built out of construction toys

304.30.text: and I realized that if I had grown up with this stuff,

307.66.text: I might have thought of myself as an engineer far younger

312.27.text: than by the time I was 18 years old

314.90.text: and so it sounds really corny,

316.43.text: but the moment she had this idea at Idea Brunch

319.85.text: of engineering toys for girls was the moment where

323.61.text: it was like the fireworks went off, the lightning bulb.

327.01.text: I just knew, oh my god, this is what I was born to do.

331.38.text: I knew it instinctively in that moment

333.50.text: and so the very next day I decided I'm gonna go

336.70.text: to the toy store and get a lay of the land here.

339.44.text: I'm sure times have changed since Christi and I were kids.

342.05.text: I'm sure there's gotta be a lot of toys for girls

346.63.text: so I went to the toy store and this is what I found.

355.50.text: So this was the most disgusting dolls

359.62.text: that look like street corner girls.

363.43.text: It was fairies, princesses, tea sets, ironing boards.

368.01.text: I mean, it was all about domesticity.

371.06.text: It's all about the way that you look.

373.85.text: Meanwhile in the blue aisle was all of the smart

377.55.text: math and science games, heroes, action figures

381.05.text: and it just felt like this isn't fair.

384.75.text: So the thing about the blue aisle was that

387.72.text: it had a lot of toys that helped develop spatial skills.

391.68.text: Now this is something as I started to do

393.42.text: research into how would I advantage girls?

396.31.text: How would I give them a leg up,

397.86.text: give them something that might prepare them for engineering?

400.75.text: Spatial skills kept coming up as underdeveloped in girls.

404.10.text: Well, interestingly, I also read that spatial skills

407.78.text: are commonly found in kids who grew up

412.15.text: Kids who played with construction toys

416.61.text: because they played with construction toys.

418.88.text: So I thought, okay, if I wanna help

423.62.text: maybe if I could get them building with construction toys,

426.28.text: then that might be a way,

428.90.text: but other construction toys had tried this before.

432.75.text: The genius approach was let's make them pink

436.46.text: and then girls will play with them.

438.38.text: Well, I noticed in the toy store

439.93.text: that these pink construction toys were sitting

442.11.text: in the corner of the aisle with dust all over them

445.03.text: and I thought maybe there's a better way

447.52.text: and so as I started to research,

450.05.text: I spent weeks and weeks observing,

453.83.text: reading every book I could on child development,

456.48.text: begging my friends to let me babysit their kids

460.37.text: I found that if I just gave a girl

463.87.text: a bunch of construction toys, a lot of times

467.91.text: she would play for a little bit and get disinterested.

471.44.text: In one of my sessions, I actually asked a bunch of girls,

474.85.text: "Well, what do you wanna play with?"

476.70.text: And a bunch of them said,

477.61.text: "Well, we actually wanna read a story.

479.62.text: "We love this new book that we got."

481.03.text: They ran upstairs and brought a book down

483.19.text: and I remember in that moment thinking, huh.

485.44.text: We have all these construction toys on the floor

487.91.text: and then we're sitting here reading this book together

490.41.text: and I noticed that girls really love

495.11.text: and so I had this kind of genius idea,

500.39.text: Why don't I incorporate storytelling with building?

503.31.text: Because a lot of boys tend to take construction toys

506.52.text: and build a big tower and then smash it against the wall,

510.16.text: but girls really liked kind of building

512.71.text: when there was more of a reason why,

514.48.text: sort of a narrative and a context,

516.48.text: so that was my big idea,

522.16.text: So this is kind of funny.

525.83.text: My grandmother was actually a pioneer.

528.51.text: She's one of the first female animators

530.77.text: and created Mr. Magoo and so I've always had

534.05.text: this love of cartooning and art

536.67.text: and so my very first prototype of GoldieBlox

539.83.text: wasn't a construction toy at all.

541.46.text: I actually drew a sketch of a little girl

544.54.text: who was not a princess, but not a nerd.

547.09.text: She was gonna be a builder and in these sketches,

550.23.text: I had Goldie building these elaborate cool machines

558.21.text: kind of what would Goldie build?

559.46.text: What would be some of the machines that she would make?

561.41.text: In this first prototype, I created a belt drive

565.73.text: where Goldie built a machine to help her dog chase his tail.

569.61.text: So this is all stuff, I'm going to the hardware store.

572.66.text: I'm rummaging through my drawers with thread spools and clay

577.02.text: and it was very these ramshackle prototypes,

579.94.text: but it was enough to kind of get my idea out

583.08.text: of a girl character in an associated building set

588.40.text: where kids could kind of build along with Goldie

591.47.text: and once I'd had this prototype,

594.59.text: I was just like, oh my god, this is genius, right?

598.04.text: Nobody has done this, this is genius

600.86.text: and so I came up with this plan, right?

603.60.text: This is my grand master plan

605.74.text: where I've got this original prototype

608.13.text: that I know is just this breakthrough idea

610.74.text: and one day I'm gonna disrupt the pink aisle

614.30.text: in every toy store with this idea.

618.23.text: So there wasn't a very straightforward

620.23.text: path to that as I had thought,

622.97.text: but in my talk today what I wanna share with you all

626.68.text: is sort of this sort of circuitous path that I took

630.76.text: from having my kind of first prototype in hand

634.52.text: to actually getting GoldieBlox onto the shelves

638.14.text: of toy stores around the world.

641.55.text: So I'm gonna start with my first step

643.62.text: and kind of my first sort of lesson learned along the way,

647.59.text: which is at the very beginning having this first prototype,

652.38.text: I had to learn the difference between

654.10.text: being an inventor and being an entrepreneur.

658.05.text: So I brought my first prototype to the New York Toy Fair

661.34.text: to get advice from the bigwigs in the toy industry

664.63.text: and very early on, and in my mind,

668.30.text: I'm like this is the best idea ever.

673.42.text: It was mainly old white men in suits

675.86.text: who run the toy industry who said, "You can't fight nature."

679.54.text: They said, "Girls wanna play in the pink aisle.

686.26.text: So at this point, I had quit my job

689.70.text: and I was going off of my life savings,

691.96.text: so this was not very good news to hear.

694.46.text: I was pretty dejected, as you can imagine

698.98.text: and right after the toy fair, I had actually signed up

701.76.text: to go to this social entrepreneurship conference

705.36.text: and to be honest, I wasn't in the mood to go at all.

708.12.text: I kind of just wanted to go home

709.65.text: and crawl up in a ball and hide,

713.27.text: but I had already signed up and I'd paid,

715.36.text: so I go to the conference

717.49.text: and it was this conference for social entrepreneurs.

721.61.text: There were about 100 people there and the deal was

724.64.text: everybody who was there had to get up

726.86.text: and share their idea in front of the room.

729.66.text: Well, I wasn't feeling so great about my idea at that moment

733.02.text: because all of those old toy men

734.74.text: had told me it was a stupid idea,

737.01.text: but I got up anyway to share the idea

741.31.text: and unlike the reception at the toy fair,

745.12.text: all of the young people at this

746.77.text: social entrepreneurship conference, they were inspired.

751.31.text: They all got up to their feet and cheered.

755.10.text: They formed a line around the building,

758.05.text: all wanting to be a part of it

760.38.text: and there was something that I learned that was

762.11.text: really helpful at that conference and it was this concept

764.52.text: of being an inventor, being an entrepreneur.

768.31.text: I learned that being an inventor means

770.28.text: that you sort of hole up alone,

772.15.text: kind of working on your idea,

773.93.text: trying to come up with something

776.14.text: and that's what I'd been doing for the last few months.

779.18.text: I'd been kind of alone in my apartment

783.80.text: and even though it was my passion,

785.97.text: it was what I knew I wanted to do

787.40.text: with my life, I was lonely.

789.64.text: I wasn't having a lot of fun

791.97.text: and I was too afraid to talk to people about my idea

794.96.text: 'cause I was afraid that some big toy company might steal it

798.19.text: and so I was just lonely.

801.18.text: The moment I went to this social entrepreneurship conference

804.00.text: and I built up the courage to get up and share my idea

806.82.text: without making somebody sign an NDA, which by the way,

810.23.text: I'd even made my mom sign one, I was so paranoid.

815.26.text: The moment I actually, I'm not even kidding.

819.15.text: I have a copy of it.

821.65.text: The moment I actually finally kind of

823.46.text: put myself out there, everything changed.

827.56.text: All of a sudden, I wasn't feeling lonely anymore.

830.03.text: I had people coming to my apartment every day.

835.74.text: We were working on the prototypes together.

838.44.text: They were helping me, they were giving me advice.

840.57.text: They were giving me ideas, just volunteering

844.19.text: because they were passionate about it.

847.28.text: They helped me kind of take that first

849.58.text: sort of ugly prototype and they helped me

852.16.text: rapidly prototype it again and again and again.

854.90.text: They helped me test it with kids.

856.77.text: We tested it with over 100 kids

859.35.text: and each time we observed kids playing with it,

862.18.text: we found ways to make it better and better

864.48.text: and so all of a sudden, I went from being

867.10.text: this kind of lone hermit inventor to being an entrepreneur

871.77.text: because the entrepreneur is somebody who shares their vision

875.86.text: and more importantly brings people along

878.96.text: and the moment that those people lined up

881.54.text: to be a part of it and I let them

884.18.text: is the moment that I became an entrepreneur

887.66.text: and so with their help, I went from this

890.67.text: lonely hermit prototype in my living room

893.34.text: to a final toy that girls loved.

897.77.text: Girls in tutus and tiaras were building belt drives

901.99.text: and loving it and so I knew I had it,

905.55.text: but the problem was I knew that all of those old people

909.61.text: in the toy industry were never gonna believe me.

912.45.text: They all thought that this was never gonna sell

914.77.text: and so I put it up on Kickstarter and before I knew it,

919.30.text: I had sold about $1,000,000 of GoldieBlox

922.69.text: in pre-orders before manufacturing a single unit

926.53.text: and so the amazing thing was that this mission

930.10.text: that I believed in, by being able to sort of

933.52.text: share my vision in a video format

936.66.text: was kind of the same way that I shared my vision

939.11.text: at that conference where I just kind of talked to people

941.94.text: about, "Hey, here's what I'm doing and here's why."

945.59.text: I was authentic and I invited people to help

949.26.text: by taking this Kickstarter, backing it

951.81.text: and making it a reality and the concept went viral.

956.32.text: All of a sudden, TechCrunch wrote it up,

958.62.text: The Atlantic, Huffington Post, it was all over the news

962.06.text: of can an engineering toy get girls interested?

964.74.text: Can an engineering toy solve the gender gap?

969.93.text: My team of three full-time employees,

976.46.text: where we started shipping out Kickstarter orders

979.21.text: and these are some of our very first backers

981.99.text: and so it very quickly in my very first year

986.43.text: went from being an inventor to an entrepreneur

989.58.text: and was very proud to go back to that toy fair

992.97.text: with my own booth one year later and sure enough,

997.03.text: who came over to the booth but Toys "R" Us?

1000.38.text: They said, "Hey, you're making us look bad.

1021.68.text: So which led us to year two

1023.79.text: and the next kind of big lesson learned for me,

1026.45.text: which is how very limited resources

1029.11.text: can actually be a big strategic advantage.

1032.53.text: So getting into Toys "R" Us nationwide

1038.67.text: I remember walking in the store for the first time

1040.37.text: and seeing the toy on the shelf and I had tears,

1043.86.text: both of joy, tears of joy

1046.63.text: that I had accomplished the impossible

1049.56.text: and also tears of dread because I just realized,

1053.64.text: oh my gosh, this toy is one tiny box in a sea of pink

1060.50.text: and how are we gonna compete?

1064.48.text: What actually started to happen was

1066.24.text: we started to get our sales results in from Toys "R" Us

1068.82.text: and the toys weren't really selling

1071.38.text: and so we had disrupted the pink aisle,

1074.14.text: but we were gonna get kicked out of there any moment

1077.37.text: unless the sales started to pick up

1079.75.text: and so I asked Toys "R" Us, "What do we do, what can we do?

1083.95.text: "Give us some ideas, we'll do anything.

1085.55.text: "We wanna get the toys to start selling."

1093.03.text: "and that usually helps get the toys to sell."

1099.26.text: That was really not in the cards

1101.30.text: and so we had to get scrappy.

1105.82.text: to the Toys "R" Us parking lot

1108.00.text: and we said, "Hey, we're gonna film a video together."

1110.15.text: Our idea was if we wanna tell the world

1112.17.text: that we're in Toys "R" Us, let's film a shot of

1114.59.text: a bunch of words running through the pink aisle screaming,

1118.28.text: so we invited our Kickstarter backers to the parking lot.

1122.50.text: About 50 people showed up, kids and their parents.

1125.60.text: We're getting ready to kind of get this stealth shot

1128.46.text: and then the security guard starts circling.

1131.51.text: I'm like, "Oh my god, we're gonna get arrested."

1135.54.text: So the manager of Toys "R" Us comes out with this clipboard

1139.10.text: and they say, "What's going on here?"

1142.18.text: So I told a little white lie.

1143.93.text: Said we were the loveliest girls club on a field trip

1147.54.text: to the girls' favorite place in the world, Toys "R" Us.

1153.33.text: "I hope we have enough gift bags."

1155.47.text: He runs in, comes back out with Geoffrey the Giraffe,

1159.55.text: handing gift bags out to the girls,

1164.06.text: We set up our video equipment, get the shot,

1166.99.text: posted the video on YouTube and we got about 1,000,000 views

1171.90.text: and the story broke that GoldieBlox broke into Toys "R" Us

1175.85.text: and it went viral and all of a sudden

1181.08.text: and so we kept trying to figure out ways,

1183.41.text: like how do we, even though we're this teeny-tiny team,

1186.20.text: we're only five people, how do we get the word out?

1189.63.text: We found out about a contest being run by Intuit

1192.70.text: where one small business had the chance

1196.02.text: to win a free Super Bowl commercial,

1198.43.text: so I'm like, okay, there's our national TV advertising.

1202.24.text: We gotta win this and so again, it sounds crazy.

1205.54.text: How could we win a Super Bowl commercial?

1207.61.text: We just put it on the wall and we said, "This is our goal."

1210.82.text: Our team of five people, every single day

1216.31.text: So we emailed our Kickstarter backers.

1218.36.text: We emailed our fans, just begged every day

1220.77.text: vote for us, vote for us, vote for us

1291.30.text: and our mission to disrupt the pink aisle

1339.17.text: and so going into year three,

1341.23.text: GoldieBlox is on top of the world.

1343.41.text: Meanwhile, we have a problem with our blocks,

1347.04.text: which leads us to kind of the next lesson learned,

1351.02.text: which is how do you turn failure into an opportunity?

1355.62.text: So my biggest fear in starting GoldieBlox

1358.44.text: is what if the girl construction toy wasn't well-engineered?

1363.08.text: What if we gave a construction toy out

1369.33.text: Where instead of getting them interested and excited

1373.95.text: It was literally my worst nightmare and I was living it,

1377.07.text: so in 2014, Super Bowl commercial, Toys "R" Us nationwide

1381.79.text: were shipping tens of thousands of units from something

1384.58.text: that had less than a year before

1387.05.text: been a prototype in my living room.

1389.12.text: Anyone who has a hardware company knows this is very common.

1394.04.text: You're gonna have problems, but this was just a whole level

1398.38.text: of something I was completely unprepared for.

1402.03.text: We started getting complaints in that the blocks

1404.18.text: were not fitting right, a little bit too loose

1407.40.text: and I was just so upset, I could barely handle it,

1414.42.text: so we thought, okay, what would we do?

1421.07.text: When you have this big hairy problem,

1423.06.text: let's break it down into simple and manageable steps, right?

1426.08.text: So what do we need to do?

1427.14.text: So first we need to fix the block hole.

1430.93.text: Great, we know how to fix it.

1432.23.text: Now we've been able to manufacture better blocks.

1435.19.text: The problem is solved, but now how do we go back

1438.02.text: and tell all of those people,

1445.15.text: So I made a pretty major executive decision

1449.87.text: and we were a small startup at the time

1452.53.text: without a lot of resources, but I thought

1454.72.text: there's no better way to deploy our resources

1457.31.text: than going back to all of those customers,

1459.56.text: telling them that we fixed our blocks

1463.14.text: and so we did a huge campaign where we reached out

1465.76.text: to everybody to tell them about our new blocks.

1468.82.text: Filmed a video myself kind of being vulnerable

1471.63.text: and talking about the mistake that we had made,

1474.71.text: but what we were doing to fix it

1477.25.text: and we also actually wrote a letter from Goldie

1481.56.text: to each kid, which we had personalized with their name

1485.63.text: talking about how engineers don't always get it right

1488.71.text: the first time, but that doesn't mean that you give up.

1490.96.text: It means that you keep going.

1492.30.text: You keep iterating and you make it better

1494.50.text: and we actually drew a picture of the engineering solution

1497.27.text: that got the block to fit better

1499.56.text: and we sent it out to every kid.

1501.38.text: We actually went and replaced 1,000,000 blocks,

1508.88.text: so we turned that failure into an opportunity

1511.56.text: and every person that we touched

1513.33.text: fell in love with our brand even more.

1516.30.text: So then I get to my next lesson on my circuitous path,

1521.80.text: which is design for the customer, not the retailer.

1529.33.text: and every retailer wants to carry it.

1532.76.text: I mean, the brand is so hot

1537.33.text: and Walmart is begging for GoldieBlox.

1540.03.text: I mean, imagine being in the situation

1542.48.text: where Walmart is begging for your product

1544.99.text: and so in order to sell at Walmart,

1546.78.text: we were told by a lot of the toy industry veterans

1550.55.text: that you have to have products at $9.99.

1555.14.text: You have to have low price point products.

1556.67.text: That's what sells at Walmart and so our whole focus

1560.18.text: for the year was, okay, we're gonna go big.

1562.79.text: GoldieBlox is gonna hit the mainstream

1567.85.text: Let's figure out how to make toys that are 10 bucks

1571.25.text: and make a lot of them 'cause we have to have

1573.20.text: a lot of products to fill up a lot of room.

1576.15.text: So we had a really small team still, about 15 people

1579.91.text: and we were just bending over backwards

1581.61.text: under insane timelines and all we're thinking about

1588.90.text: and hitting the shelf date on time.

1593.43.text: What ended up happening was we worked

1596.28.text: as hard and as fast as we could.

1598.20.text: We went from six products to 18 products

1602.36.text: in less than a year, getting out as many products

1605.22.text: as we could at the cheapest prices that we could

1608.53.text: and as a result, those cheap products

1615.67.text: We had kind of forgotten the most important thing,

1619.47.text: which is if GoldieBlox was gonna be successful,

1622.82.text: we have to design for the girls.

1626.04.text: Every product, it doesn't matter how much it costs.

1628.44.text: If it's not a product that excites

1632.17.text: in wanting to build more and more, we've failed

1636.42.text: and so by the end of the year, we had gone from

1640.47.text: sort of being on the top of the world to sort of

1643.50.text: hitting this real reality, major major reality check,

1649.59.text: which leads me to my final lesson

1653.21.text: which is never ever give up.

1656.78.text: So kind of every startup is a roller coaster, you know?

1661.20.text: At one moment, you're at the top of the world

1662.92.text: and I feel like we at this moment had sort of

1665.42.text: gone right back down to the bottom again

1668.24.text: and so we had to sort of have a soul-searching moment

1670.50.text: of where do we go from here?

1675.46.text: So we thought, okay, let's forget about

1681.52.text: Let's forget about the toy aisle.

1684.55.text: Let's forget about disrupting the toy aisle.

1686.84.text: Let's think about making the best possible products

1692.06.text: Let's think about what have we done so far

1695.03.text: that girls really love and let's lean into that

1698.60.text: and so as we started to look at that

1700.40.text: and think about it more and more,

1702.54.text: we'd realized that in fact what girls were really loving

1705.78.text: about GoldieBlox, they were loving building

1709.10.text: and we were introducing it to them in a new way,

1712.16.text: which was good, but what we noticed they loved the most

1716.01.text: was they loved the idea of this character Goldie.

1719.94.text: They were dressing up as her for Halloween.

1722.58.text: They were wanting to, they were admiring her

1726.25.text: and every time we had kind of introduced Goldie

1728.85.text: and her friends to them, these characters

1731.62.text: and these stories, that was what was really engaging them

1734.98.text: and that was what was really unique about us.

1737.88.text: Tinkertoy doesn't do that and K'NEX doesn't do that.

1741.31.text: You know, the construction toys don't do that.

1742.82.text: That was something really special about us.

1744.87.text: It was really the stories and so we started

1749.02.text: leaning into that more and more and really kind of

1751.98.text: thinking more and more and spending our time

1754.48.text: not focusing on what can we make for $9.99,

1757.74.text: but focusing on how would we create this role model,

1761.02.text: Goldie, to really become a role model of girls?

1766.10.text: To really become kind of an inspiring maker?

1775.24.text: What town does she live in?

1776.44.text: What kind of things does she build?

1778.46.text: We started writing much richer and deeper stories

1781.86.text: and really started figuring out who is this girl?

1786.12.text: And can we really develop enough story about this character

1791.17.text: that she will be somebody that every girl

1793.51.text: falls in love with and wants to be?

1798.07.text: So we started leaning into that more and more

1801.76.text: and just yesterday, we actually announced

1804.86.text: chapter books with our partner, Random House,

1807.91.text: and so now we'll start to get out

1811.09.text: these really rich stories about this girl

1813.78.text: who believe it or not, is literally the first

1818.49.text: girl engineer protagonist in children's entertainment.

1823.70.text: It took until 2012 for somebody to create

1827.02.text: a girl engineer in children's entertainment

1829.84.text: and so now we have chapter books coming out about Goldie.

1833.82.text: We started figuring out how do we

1837.36.text: We started just experimenting on YouTube

1844.05.text: just as quickly as we could with stories about Goldie.

1847.14.text: We took our little toy character

1849.84.text: and we created a web video series called Toy Hackers

1854.98.text: where in each episode, our little toys

1857.89.text: would have to solve engineering problems

1861.28.text: and so they would get a prompt and just using

1864.70.text: common household objects in each episode,

1872.18.text: and every week we'd put up a new episode

1874.92.text: where we just made them in our office

1877.58.text: and the videos started to climb

1879.55.text: where we would get views and more views and more views

1884.96.text: watching the content started to go up.

1888.30.text: We started to think, well, how else can we get Goldie,

1891.50.text: this character, out in front of kids

1894.26.text: in a way that we can control it,

1896.25.text: we can own it, and we can do it scrappy?

1900.29.text: We took all of our toy parts

1903.47.text: and we put them into curriculum kits

1906.66.text: where we could get it into the classroom

1908.83.text: and have kind of STEM educational curriculum

1920.19.text: go into the entire education market?

1923.33.text: Well, all we did was call up our friend

1928.65.text: who was an elementary school teacher

1930.47.text: and ask her if she would help

1932.52.text: and she literally did it in exchange for free toys

1936.09.text: and she called up her other friends

1938.03.text: and before we knew it, we had all of these teachers

1940.64.text: passionately wanting to create GoldieBlox curriculum

1944.82.text: for students and coming by the office every day

1949.04.text: and putting stuff together, going out into classrooms,

1952.25.text: testing it with kids and showing how

1954.82.text: we could have this character, Goldie,

1957.44.text: kind of walk kids through STEM curriculum in a way

1961.32.text: that wasn't intimidating for the kids or the teachers

1965.57.text: and so we started launching these classroom kits.

1971.58.text: and we started developing a bible for an animated series

1976.24.text: and so really kind of thinking about

1979.24.text: if Disney Princess over the last 10 years

1984.87.text: has built an entire lifestyle around being a princess

1988.57.text: with cartoons and films and apps and books

1992.13.text: and room decor and costumes where every little girl

1995.78.text: gets to live out a princess fantasy,

1998.66.text: we started to kind of shift our strategy

2000.44.text: and think, well, how could GoldieBlox

2002.78.text: enable that maker culture, that maker lifestyle?

2007.29.text: How do we enable every little girl to be a maker?

2010.78.text: And how does GoldieBlox, the character and her friends

2015.30.text: inspire girls to wanna build and invent,

2017.75.text: not just do their hair or put on makeup?

2022.19.text: So it's been a very circuitous path,

2030.18.text: just to recap kind of the lessons learned over the years.

2033.69.text: So number one, the concept of being an entrepreneur

2039.99.text: I think has been so important.

2044.78.text: Again, the notion of just hustling,

2048.74.text: bringing people onboard and I think one thing

2052.02.text: to point out about that that's important

2056.77.text: is when you have something like GoldieBlox

2059.55.text: that has a social mission that's bigger than you

2062.06.text: where if you succeed, it's going to benefit other people,

2065.15.text: it's gonna help change the world,

2067.30.text: it kind of gives you the mojo to go out

2071.87.text: and make kind of audacious asks

2074.54.text: and go ask people to get involved and be a part of it

2080.69.text: It's in a way where you know that

2083.12.text: you're doing something bigger than yourself

2085.20.text: and I think that's what really enabled me

2086.90.text: to sort of act like that entrepreneur

2089.17.text: when normally I often wasn't the kind of person

2091.98.text: who enjoyed networking or that kind of stuff.

2096.90.text: There was something about the social mission of it

2099.07.text: that enabled me to really start acting like an entrepreneur.

2104.67.text: The limited resources being a strategic advantage,

2107.37.text: so anyone who goes into entrepreneurship will face this.

2111.85.text: I mean, it's the whole point.

2115.83.text: you're gonna have very very limited resources

2118.43.text: and to even think that GoldieBlox could one day

2122.61.text: become as big as Disney Princess,

2129.46.text: Yet, to think that Debbie Sterling

2132.94.text: could graduate from Stanford with an engineering degree

2138.63.text: and yet if you kind of put that goal out there

2143.16.text: and you learn that you can achieve things,

2145.84.text: you start to realize, hey, you can get there

2150.66.text: if you break these things down

2154.03.text: and sometimes having those fewer resources

2157.95.text: means you're an underdog, you know?

2162.30.text: They wanna be a part of it

2163.96.text: and sometimes when you don't have that many resources,

2167.43.text: it forces you to think outside the box.

2169.94.text: Would a big toy company ever break into

2172.73.text: Toys "R" Us and almost get arrested?

2175.33.text: No, but that's what makes us so awesome.

2181.00.text: The next lesson, which is turning

2190.52.text: I see girls being afraid to fail.

2192.81.text: I see little girls being so obsessed with perfection

2199.39.text: that they almost don't wanna try something

2201.19.text: if they think they're gonna be bad at it.

2204.17.text: That's something that I wanna overcome with GoldieBlox.

2206.50.text: I wanna let them know that engineering is all about failing

2210.29.text: and failing is great because when you fail

2213.32.text: and you learn something from it and then you succeed later,

2221.23.text: and if you're not comfortable with failure,

2223.36.text: you're never gonna be able to succeed as an entrepreneur,

2226.60.text: so rather than being so afraid to fail, you don't even try.

2231.87.text: Just leaning into failure and taking every failure

2236.39.text: as an opportunity to learn something new.

2242.81.text: This may be the biggest lesson I've learned overall.

2246.38.text: I can't stress enough as you go into entrepreneurship,

2250.71.text: you start building your business, you'll have investors.

2254.58.text: You'll have people kind of all pushing for different things

2257.54.text: and at the end of the day,

2261.48.text: if you're not focused 100% on your customer and in our case,

2266.80.text: honoring the little girl, then you've missed the mark

2272.89.text: and so just always remembering that, who your customer is

2275.62.text: and just staying true to that and defending it.

2278.73.text: Then the last one is never ever giving up.

2286.80.text: For me, I think if I wasn't just so obsessed

2291.24.text: with achieving this mission, delivering this to girls,

2294.39.text: of giving every girl around the world

2296.01.text: kind of that nudge that my engineering teacher gave me,

2299.69.text: that to me it's just what gets me up every morning

2302.60.text: and so I've had so many failures

2308.68.text: So many moments where quietly I've wanted to give up.

2313.22.text: So many things that didn't work out the way I'd planned

2316.37.text: and having to go back into the office

2317.77.text: every morning with a big smile,

2319.64.text: having to go and put myself out there and pitch

2322.53.text: or be on the news when I know in the back of my head

2325.47.text: things actually aren't really working out.

2330.17.text: That's what every entrepreneur goes through

2332.51.text: and the ones who are successful

2335.04.text: are the ones who refuse to give up.

2339.49.text: So just closing my talk 'cause we're gonna go

2343.04.text: into Q and A here, but it has been

2346.22.text: a wild ride toward disrupting the pink aisle

2349.32.text: and I think what I've learned along the way

2351.87.text: is it was amazing that I achieved that

2356.50.text: in such a short amount of time,

2358.17.text: but it actually wasn't the big goal

2364.82.text: that I really needed to do

2367.89.text: and now I'm focused on an even bigger goal,

2371.43.text: which is really building this character brand

2375.79.text: to become sort of the face,

2377.83.text: if you will, of the maker generation.

2379.78.text: So for every little girl who grows up

2382.39.text: with her princess face, I'm gonna give her her maker face.

2386.96.text: I don't think that it's going to be a very straight path.

2389.66.text: (laughs) I suspect that that arrow will break

2395.56.text: but I couldn't enjoy the ride more.

2410.04.text: So I think we have about 15ish minutes for Q and A.

2416.19.text: - [Audience Member] So I'm a guy, I'm an engineer.

2420.66.text: and so I'm doing my best to try and encourage her

2423.10.text: in this way and getting these GoldieBlox,

2424.80.text: but I'm wondering what thinking you've given to those

2428.42.text: who maybe don't come from my background.

2430.45.text: You know, some of it comes naturally then to my daughter,

2432.94.text: but some of it also is unnatural.

2434.58.text: I didn't have sisters or things like that,

2437.67.text: so what about helping mothers and fathers

2439.89.text: who don't come from engineering backgrounds

2442.44.text: the same as you're doing for teachers?

2445.87.text: Yeah, so I think one of the reasons why GoldieBlox

2451.39.text: was kind of this breakout was because I think we realized

2457.05.text: early on that most people aren't advanced engineers

2462.45.text: and there are very few women who are engineers

2464.76.text: and so if this product line was only focused

2468.73.text: around people who really deeply understand engineering,

2471.90.text: we were gonna have a pretty niche market

2478.75.text: and we continue to do this more and more,

2480.89.text: was how do we introduce these engineering concepts

2484.06.text: in such a way that it is accessible to anybody

2487.11.text: so you don't need to have an engineering degree?

2490.24.text: How do you make it fun?

2491.83.text: How do you make it so that kids

2493.61.text: are building and playing with stuff

2495.11.text: and they don't even know that they're learning something?

2497.99.text: So that was really our goal

2500.14.text: and I would say that along the way

2502.39.text: as we've been developing more and more products

2504.29.text: and kind of seeing how people have reacted with them,

2509.18.text: if anything I've learned that really

2511.87.text: the more fun you make it and the less you try

2517.07.text: and kind of make it feel like you're in school, the better

2520.57.text: and I think what we have found that helps

2526.77.text: is kind of from the product experience,

2529.61.text: it needs to be so fun,

2531.66.text: kids don't even realize they're learning,

2534.36.text: but offering parents tools, parents who are interested

2537.67.text: in getting their kids interested in this stuff.

2540.44.text: We've been actually offering a lot in our social media.

2543.64.text: So sharing articles or tips on how

2545.74.text: to get your kids interested, pointing out, hey,

2548.61.text: you can teach your kid this, you can teach your kid that,

2552.62.text: so we've really sort of separated it out

2554.40.text: so the play experience, the toys have to be fun.

2556.84.text: It's a toy, but we have found ways

2559.93.text: of sort of engaging with parents

2561.62.text: sort of separately on those platforms.

2566.19.text: - [Audience Member] So it seems that you didn't have

2567.96.text: investments in the first few years,

2570.32.text: so what is different with that and what is

2572.75.text: the biggest difference after you got the investment?

2578.29.text: The question was it seems like we didn't,

2586.07.text: So at the beginning I was really

2590.72.text: building the company off of my life savings,

2593.60.text: so I had quit my job and I had saved up

2596.57.text: a certain amount of money in my bank account

2598.52.text: and was like, okay, this money's gonna last me a year

2601.88.text: to really go for this because I had been

2603.91.text: kind of working on nights and weekends

2605.70.text: and in my spare time and I had just gotten to the point

2607.82.text: where I'm like, I'm never gonna get somewhere

2612.02.text: if I just only do it in my spare time.

2614.42.text: I gotta go all in or it's never gonna happen

2617.15.text: and so it was scary to do that

2619.06.text: 'cause I'm like, well, what if I fail?

2622.49.text: But then I thought, okay, what's the worst case scenario

2625.31.text: here is that I spend a year of my life savings,

2628.19.text: I run out of money, it didn't work out

2630.96.text: and so I'll just go get a job, you know?

2635.46.text: I'll never regret kind of giving it a real go

2638.43.text: of something that I was passionate about.

2640.02.text: Even if it doesn't work out, I would never regret that

2642.67.text: and so at the beginning, kind of going off

2644.08.text: of my life savings, one of the benefits of that

2648.35.text: was that with such few resources,

2651.51.text: I didn't have the money to spend on expensive prototypes

2654.69.text: and as a result, I had to make quick and dirty prototypes

2658.02.text: and they weren't as precious to me

2659.87.text: and so I'd be willing to just toss the idea

2665.17.text: convincing myself that it was a great idea

2667.31.text: even though observing kids hating it, you know?

2670.94.text: So there was a huge advantage

2673.38.text: to just going off my life savings.

2675.09.text: Another thing was that because I didn't have

2677.36.text: a huge investment, I decided to do crowdfunding.

2683.51.text: If I had raised a bunch of money at the beginning,

2685.35.text: I probably wouldn't have done crowdfunding.

2686.83.text: I probably would have gone the traditional route

2688.94.text: of selling into brick and mortar stores,

2691.37.text: but by doing crowdfunding, it was actually

2693.73.text: a very great marketing tool because it put the idea out

2696.97.text: and it ended up going viral and so these were just

2701.12.text: great things that happened out of me

2703.66.text: kind of going off at the beginning with my life savings.

2707.32.text: We raised our first major round of capital right after

2712.22.text: the Kickstarter had kind of gone through the roof

2716.35.text: and there was a huge change after that.

2719.38.text: I think the biggest thing is once you start

2720.86.text: raising real money, it really enables you

2725.95.text: is probably one of the biggest changes

2728.04.text: and so very quickly it went from sort of feeling like

2732.41.text: volunteers, you're in an apartment to you're a company.

2749.09.text: The other thing is once you take in money,

2750.90.text: then you have investors who have certain expectations

2754.40.text: and a lot of times the investors wanna see you make

2758.70.text: as much money as quickly as possible

2761.11.text: and many times that's actually maybe not

2764.66.text: the best thing that you should be doing

2766.55.text: and so one last thing, I'm kind of rambling here,

2770.46.text: but I think that I've learned that took me a real long time

2773.38.text: to learn that I know now is it's really good to,

2777.76.text: you know, it's important to find great investors,

2780.59.text: but it's also important to find

2781.89.text: really great strategic advisors as well

2784.42.text: who are really deeply knowledgeable about your space

2788.28.text: and it's really important to formalize things,

2792.62.text: whether it's quarterly board meetings or whatever,

2795.20.text: to make sure that the investors

2797.36.text: who have money in the company,

2798.70.text: but also the advisors who know the right things

2801.33.text: you should be doing are all in the same room

2804.32.text: so that if the investor's saying, "No, sell, sell, sell.

2809.54.text: And you're on the phone like, "Okay, okay."

2811.36.text: Then on the phone with the other advisor, "Don't do that.

2817.57.text: Bring them together 'cause as soon as you start

2821.30.text: taking money and there's just a lot of pressures

2823.53.text: and outside expectations that you need to answer to

2827.36.text: and it's good to kind of get the right people in the room

2830.12.text: sort of discussing it as a group rather than separately.

2835.23.text: - [Audience Member] What are your thoughts on

2836.93.text: measuring the impact of GoldieBlox on girls'

2844.50.text: - The question was how do you measure the impact

2846.53.text: of GoldieBlox on girls' motor skills

2854.01.text: So early on, I had to decide whether I was gonna set up

2858.34.text: GoldieBlox as a for-profit or not-for-profit

2861.26.text: and it was a kind of tricky thing

2862.99.text: 'cause I'm like, well, GoldieBlox could be a nonprofit

2865.46.text: because it's doing this great social mission,

2868.56.text: but at the same time it's a consumer product

2870.91.text: and it could be a for-profit company

2873.31.text: and I wasn't sure which way to go

2874.77.text: and actually part of the reason why

2876.47.text: I chose the for-profit route was I felt like

2879.80.text: it would be a faster way to achieve our goals.

2885.55.text: The nonprofit route requires you to do

2887.85.text: a lot of measurement on things

2889.95.text: that I sort of felt like might be difficult to measure.

2892.35.text: It might take a really long time to measure

2894.68.text: and so I'd worked in the nonprofit world before

2898.25.text: and I had seen those challenges

2900.13.text: and so right now the way I measure

2903.19.text: GoldieBlox's success is a few things.

2905.47.text: So one, a lot of it's anecdotal.

2911.23.text: So every day we get photos and letters and videos

2915.39.text: of kids and their parents writing in,

2917.31.text: telling us how GoldieBlox has changed their lives.

2920.86.text: Girls kind of calling themselves engineers.

2924.54.text: "I can't believe that she even knows what that is."

2927.19.text: Those are kind of anecdotal ways where we're like,

2931.13.text: The other way to just tell we're making a difference

2933.00.text: is how many kids are buying our toys

2936.43.text: and coming back and buying more

2938.07.text: because if they're buying them and playing with them,

2939.89.text: then we know that they're building

2943.97.text: Then the other way is there have been universities

2947.84.text: and sort of third parties who have been interested

2949.63.text: in the effects that you're talking about

2951.55.text: and so we have given them the green light

2953.43.text: to go and conduct research studies,

2955.48.text: which is really great because then

2956.64.text: we're not conducting our own research study

2958.54.text: where then we can go publish some article

2960.23.text: about the change that we made where we stacked the deck

2963.06.text: and made it seem better than it was.

2966.42.text: in these unbiased third party studies.

2968.54.text: One recently came out that was done by Penn State

2970.74.text: over a period of three years and it's fascinating

2974.45.text: and it's gonna be published publicly soon.

2980.17.text: - [Audience Member] How are you going to

2983.74.text: put the product in poor countries?

2989.57.text: How are we gonna sell the product in poor countries?

2993.48.text: So growing internationally is a beast unto itself.

3005.28.text: I have learned the hard way that focusing

3009.91.text: on getting things right sort of first in the U.S.

3012.80.text: and under things that you can control

3014.53.text: even when there's a lot of countries all around the world

3016.57.text: that are asking for it, it's better to kind of get things

3020.27.text: really optimized first in kind of the U.S.,

3024.53.text: but then keeping in mind your long-term goal

3027.33.text: of wanting to make it available

3028.85.text: to little kids all around the world.

3033.08.text: Our plan for that is actually by creating an animated series

3041.25.text: and distributing that globally and finding a partner

3044.20.text: that gets that out all around the world,

3046.53.text: will enable us for more kids to find out

3049.36.text: about GoldieBlox all around the world

3051.44.text: and once we've done that, then that enables us

3053.89.text: to find partners who are gonna create GoldieBlox products

3057.60.text: that are available to those kids around the world

3060.35.text: and once we've done that, we'll be able to find partners

3063.41.text: like great foundations or nonprofits that wanna help pay

3067.53.text: to make it available to kids who can't afford it.

3073.05.text: - It's really inspiring and I literally was moved to tears

3076.50.text: many times during your talk 'cause it's just so important

3079.19.text: and I'm curious about sort of building on

3081.86.text: this last question, this GoldieBlox has blonde hair

3086.42.text: and blue eyes and looks like certain types of kids.

3091.94.text: Are you planning on sort of making a more diverse set

3095.38.text: of characters that might be more relevant

3097.84.text: for kids who don't look like that?

3099.76.text:
(audience members applaud)
- Yeah, we actually have.

3102.88.text: I don't know if you can really see,

3104.33.text: but Goldie's best friend, so Ruby who's African American,

3109.52.text: Li who's Chinese, and Farrah is Hispanic,

3113.00.text: so we actually already have a crew of diverse characters,

3116.21.text: which is incredibly important to me.

3118.36.text: Goldie's sort of our main hero protagonist,

3121.26.text: so she's like our Harry Potter if you will,

3123.87.text: but her friends are ethnically diverse.

3129.53.text: - [Audience Member] Do you see any potential problems

3131.11.text: with having the minority characters as supporting roles,

3134.38.text: as opposed to playing a protagonist role?

3137.79.text: - You know, a lot of kids properties right now

3143.25.text: are worried about that and so what they end up creating

3146.68.text: for their franchises are sort of friend ensembles,

3151.69.text: so if you see like, I don't know

3153.32.text: if you're familiar with DC Super Hero Girls.

3156.28.text: They have eight girls and they all have the same body type,

3160.13.text: but they all have each ethnicity.

3165.13.text: A group of six girls of every color.

3169.05.text: Monster High, all of them do the same thing.

3173.19.text: They have the group and I thought about that

3176.85.text: and my approach is I really think

3182.63.text: and what I'm excited about is really creating

3186.76.text: kind of more of an iconic hero if you will,

3191.58.text: a girl who is an engineer

3195.41.text: and there never really was one before.

3200.19.text: Most kind of main girl characters are princesses

3203.64.text: and beauty queens or pop stars.

3206.88.text: I wanted to create an iconic girl maker

3209.76.text: and when I first drew the picture of her,

3213.83.text: and I didn't really think anything of it.

3215.16.text: I just gave her blonde hair

3216.58.text: 'cause her name was GoldieBlox, you know?

3218.94.text: I kind of drew a girl that looked like me 'cause I was

3222.43.text: sort of making a little mini Debbie as a cartoon character.

3227.75.text: I feel I'm excited in the stories that we're telling

3231.27.text: about this girl who's like a Pippi Longstocking,

3234.30.text: Punky Brewster, unique eccentric individual who's a maker

3239.39.text: and by kind of building her up as an iconic girl

3245.35.text: and she will have friends of other ethnicities,

3248.15.text: but I think that there's really strong

3256.67.text: is pretty gender-specific in its choices of

3262.30.text: so what role do you think gender-specific toys

3264.83.text: play in forming gender stereotypes in our community?

3270.40.text: - The question was around gender-specific marketing

3275.16.text: or colors or that GoldieBlox seems like

3278.70.text: it's very targeted to girls and what's my opinion

3282.27.text: on gender-specific marketing in general in toys?

3285.59.text: So when I was first kind of choosing the color palette

3290.79.text: for GoldieBlox, I had a big choice to make,

3293.67.text: which was I can go pastel pink and purple,

3297.59.text: which is what's very popular for girls

3299.40.text: and is common to the pink aisle.

3304.04.text: which is primary red, blue, and green,

3307.94.text: which in the construction category is so commonly boy

3314.37.text: that I think most people would just assume

3316.33.text: that that is for boys and so instead of going,

3320.01.text: and I wanted to make sure that

3321.06.text: girls were gonna play with it,

3322.51.text: so I didn't want it to be confused

3323.78.text: for something that was for boys

3326.02.text: 'cause my goal was I want to really give girls an advantage

3330.70.text: that they had been missing out on

3331.94.text: because they hadn't been marketed to

3334.00.text: and so I opted for just an entirely different color palette,

3337.85.text: which was just all kinds of bright and modern colors

3344.41.text: and green and brown and all kinds of colors

3347.28.text: and so that was the color palette that we went with.

3353.65.text: because they want it to be girlier

3356.62.text: they want it to be more gender-neutral,

3358.73.text: but I think my goal is that as long as most girls

3364.87.text: are excited about it and wanna play with it,

3367.98.text: I'm somebody who personally really likes

3370.09.text: the color pink myself, so I don't have anything against it

3372.73.text: and one thing that's kind of funny that I've learned

3374.82.text: is that boys, despite the fact that GoldieBlox

3377.87.text: has pink in it, couldn't care less

3379.80.text: and love playing with it anyway

3381.53.text: and they think that this Goldie character's pretty cool,

3384.45.text: so my view on the future of gender marketing toward kids

3388.59.text: is that I think that those lines are really blurring

3390.77.text: and that kids are kind of no longer,

3394.27.text: it's really blurring, which is exciting.

3400.39.text: Thank you so much for this incredibly inspiring talk.
